001package squidpony.squidmath;
002
003/**
004 * A mid-to-low quality point hash that uses a similar (not identical) technique to what OpenSimplex2 uses, with
005 * a permutation array created at construction. To get an x,y,z point, this looks up x in the permutation array (using
006 * only the bottom 11 bits of x), which gets an 11-bit number, then XORs that with y, masks to 11 bits, and looks that
007 * up again in the same permutation array, finishing by XORing with z and masking to 11 bits. To match the behavior of
008 * other IPointHash implementations, this finishes by attempting to include variable state using:
009 * {@code (((...) - state ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 + state ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493;}, which also pushes the usable bits
010 * up throughout the returned int, instead of just in the lowest 11 bits.
011 * <br>
012 * This is fast in OpenSimplex2, but the quality is so lackluster here, even with extra operations, that this isn't
013 * recommended at all.
014 */
015public class PermPointHash extends IPointHash.IntImpl {
016
017    public PermPointHash() {
018        this(1234567890);
019    }
020
021    private final short[] perm;
022
023    public PermPointHash(int state) {
024        super(state);
025        perm = new short[2048];
026        short[] source = new short[2048];
027        for (short i = 0; i < 2048; i++)
028            source[i] = i;
029        long s = (state ^ 0x6C8E9CF570932BD5L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
030        for (int i = 2047; i >= 0; i--) {
031            s = (s ^ 0x6C8E9CF570932BD5L) * 0xC6BC279692B5CC83L;
032            int r = (int) ((s >>> 32) * i >>> 32);
033            perm[i] = source[r];
034            source[r] = source[i];
035        }
036    }
037
038    public int getState() {
039        return state;
040    }
041
042    @Override
043    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int state) {
044        return (((perm[x & 2047] ^ y & 2047) - state ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 + state ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493;
045    }
046
047    @Override
048    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int state) {
049        return (((perm[perm[x & 2047] ^ y & 2047] ^ z & 2047) - state ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 + state ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493;
050    }
051
052    @Override
053    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int state) {
054        return (((perm[perm[perm[x & 2047] ^ y & 2047] ^ z & 2047] ^ w & 2047) - state ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 + state ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493;
055    }
056
057    @Override
058    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int state) {
059        return (((perm[perm[perm[perm[x & 2047] ^ y & 2047] ^ z & 2047] ^ w & 2047] ^ u & 2047) - state ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 + state ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493;
060    }
061
062    @Override
063    public int hashWithState(int x, int y, int z, int w, int u, int v, int state) {
064        return (((perm[perm[perm[perm[perm[x & 2047] ^ y & 2047] ^ z & 2047] ^ w & 2047] ^ u & 2047] ^ v & 2047) - state ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493 + state ^ 0xD1B54A35) * 0x125493;
065    }
066}
